plist.p: So, good morning, everyone. Many thanks for being connected with us. We have enrollment just before our AGM and we have the conference broadcasted and in teleconference for our first quarter results.
As usual, I am here with the three deputy CEOs. So shall we go directly the presentation so we will have room for question-and-answer. The usual executive summary.

The first quarter net profit is just above 1 billion, 1.007 million. The commercial banking had a very good performance, so the net profit in this area has been higher than the previous year by 15%, with the revenue growth of 8.4%, coming from Central/Eastern Europe, which is a growth provider for the group, but also from retail Italy, which continue to perform quite well.

Corporate also, private banking is quite resilient in this type of the actual market conditions. Market investment banking shows a resilient revenue base. You will see the number later on split by the ABS portfolio and the other revenue lines.

In the revenue base in market, actually market credit related activities has been 700 million in the first quarter and you will see the comparisons, not only due to the first quarter of '07, which has been an exceptional quarter for all the industry as well as for us, but mainly with the fourth quarter last year and you will see the growth. And we had 1 billion negative revenue impact in market-related activities, mainly coming from the ABS portfolio in line with the sensitivity we have provided to you.

The cost control is quite solid. In the first quarter year-on-year we had a growth of 1.2%. If we wouldn't consider Central/Eastern Europe, we would have a decreased by 3.6%. The decrease is even higher at constant ForEx and perimeter, but this is the stated number. So we would say that without Central/Eastern Europe the strategy we have put in place also with Capitalia is paying significantly, because this cost reduction is mainly coming from the restructuring we are realizing.

In Italy we had a significant reduction of staff, close to 1500 people less in the first quarter vis-à-vis the year-end coming from Capitalia integration. The Asset Quality trend is confirmed, both gross and net impaired loans are down quarter-on-quarter and the coverage ratio is up.

The Core Tier 1 ratio is 5.5% under Basel I, including the payment we made in the first quarter of this year of Ukrotsbank, this acquisition do have an impact of 22 basis points. So we continue to confirm our target in terms of Core Tier 1 of 6%. By the year-end you will see the path for achieving this number.

Talking of the first quarter results, then I will go through some divisional highlights and some conclusions. Here we have the numbers line by line. Total revenues are down year-on-year by 16.5%, quarter-on-quarter 9.3%. Driven, you will see, by MIB. As you the mark-to-market do have a negative impact on revenue. Thirdly, costs are at 1.2% year-on-year and flat on quarterly base. The operating profit currently is down by 36.5% year-on-year, 22.4% quarter-on-quarter.

Net write-downs are higher than the previous year by 21.8% and 31.8 quarter-on-quarter. You will see the explanations of these numbers, we are exactly in line with our plan. And the non-operating items are down significantly, the integration costs as well. So, at the end the net income for the group pre-PPA is 1.90 billion, 47% lower than the previous year and 15.8 on the last quarter.

I already talked of the net income; the cost income ratio is at 64.2% related to this negative revenue base. The cost of risk is at 56 basis points. We have 180,000 employees. Coming, you will see the growth in the last quarter is at 10,800 people, 10,700 of these people are Ukrsotsbankers, so is the consolidation of a new entity.

In terms of branches, we are at 850 more than the previous year – it's a large bank, and 587 on the last quarter. You will see again the number is partly related to the acquisition of all Ukrsotsbank and at the year-on-year and quarter-on-quarter Ukrsotsbank, but is also partly related to the 101 opening of new branches in Central/Eastern Europe as well as 41 branches in Italy. You will see it later on. So, it's related to this plan that we have in Central/Eastern Europe, the Italian opening branches is a tale of the last -- of the plan that we had in retail for covering better and longer in those countries. And so, it was quite important for us to have a full coverage of the area we won there.

Talking of the revenue base splitting, again, commercial banking from investment banking. You see that retail is up year on year by 4.3%. We think It's pretty good, is related to Italy and you will see the breakdown on Germany and Austria. In Germany and Austria, the first quarter last year was quite good on the commission base. We had a reduction in the first quarter of this year vis-à-vis the first quarter of '07. But again, Italy is still performing particularly well. Central and Eastern Europe is up by 24.8%. Without Ukrsotsbank at the -- the growth would be above 11%.

Corporate is up by 3.2% and again, in corporate, we are doing quite well across all the geographies. Private banking despite of the market condition is up by 1.3%. So overall, the commercial banking is growing despite of the market conditions that are clearly not exceptional is -- are up by 8.4%. So, we think that is quite good.

Asset management is affected by the market condition and the redemption. So market condition, in the sense that there are also performance fees that have not been collected in the first quarter of this year, so we are down by 17%. And maybe you will see the number, well, a negative revenue base due to this market turmoil on the IBX. We had negative revenues, close to 1 billion euro that considering the 700 million we had in the other business line goes down to the 300 million negative you are seeing there.

Talking of the different revenue lines, the net interest income is doing quite well, 13.5% year-on-year. We have to consider that partly the net commission you will see in retail, the outflows we had in asset management where is gone -- is gone partially to deposits and partially to assets under custody. So when we are seeing the two revenue lines, net interest income and the commission, we have to consider also partially one with the other. But again, in net interest income we had an exceptional result at 13.5% growth year-on-year, 2.1% quarter-on-quarter, which is a quite good and net commissions are down, mainly driven by commission from investment services. We will give you a detail later on. Trading income is negative by 683 million due to what I was talking before so is not really under comparison with the previous year.

We are doing quite well both in terms of growth in customer loan and deposits. We have a different divisions and in terms of performance year-on-year on both the lines. Customer loans in Central/Eastern Europe is up by close to 40% year-on-year, would be 23.8% at constant ForEx and perimeter again. The difference in terms of perimeter is related to at the Ukrsotsbank.

The retail is up by 5.6% is 11.7% in Italy. We have – we continue the reduction of the less profitable assets in Germany, so in Germany we have a negative trend. This is related to a choice, strategic choice we made in 2005 after the acquisition of HVB. Corporate is doing quite well. We have growth of 8.4%, is 9.9% in Italy and very solid growth both in Germany and Austria.

The customer deposits are also banking is not relevant. Quite clearly, this is mainly a service we are providing to the large private banking customers. So it's not relevant, the trend in terms of overall is, I think, quite significant on the contrary because we have in the deposit base and in private banking because again this is related to the fact that our customers are shifting assets from assets under management to liquidity and is a sort of parking place. We are sure that these assets will go back to more profitable asset base for the bank.

But as you can see we have also a very good growth in corporate Central/Eastern Europe as well as in retail. The deposit spread – spread is widening and the re-pricing actions on the loan side in order to offset the higher cost we are offending is ongoing, I have to say quite well, mainly in the first quarter of this year.

Net commissions. I think that this is pretty relevant with breakdown, because do an explanation -- given explanation on what is going on. We had a decrease by 16% in net commissions coming from investment services, partially due also to a mix of bond, which has been placed where we have sold more our own bonds than bond of third party. This is, more or less, 90 million of this difference.

Then we have, clearly, lower asset management fees for convenient of outsourcing in the first quarter. Over 19% of this outflow is captive. And I'll give you later on when I talk of retail with you on -- where these assets are going. So at the end, this is related to this two effects. On the other side, the other net commissions in reality are flat, because if we don't consider 40 million of fees that were coming from the Custodian bank in Germany. The number is perfectly flat.

We have in retail a reduction in terms of fees on the current account, because we have sold a significant number. More than 20, 50,000 in the first quarter of the current account was €1 fee per month in order to be able – our Genus One – in order to be able to reduce significantly the cost base is a current account where we had a very low fee, related to the fact that our customer have to use non-physical channels, so it is quite important.

The other lines are moving pretty well. Quite clearly, we had a reduction in Corporate and MIB of fees on the structured finance activity. This fee base was year-on-year. The delta is close to €90 million and is related to the actual market condition. So I would say that the other lines are moving pretty well because as I said before in reality it is flat.

Cost. The great number is at constant ForEx and perimeter. The white one in the circle is the stated number. As you can see, staff expenses are down by 1.8% year-on-year. At constant ForEx and perimeter, they would be lower by 3.4%. So is quite a significant reduction. Clearly, we have lower variable compensation in MIB and asset management as well as a significant head count rationalization across the Group. Italy is, as I said quite importantly, we will see a detail in the next pages.

We have a negative impact from labor contract renewals in Italy and Germany, which is more or less 30 million. We have a significant growth in Central/Eastern Europe, 12.4% at constant ForEx and perimeter, mainly due to network expansion as well as partially, contract renewal.

Other administrative expenses are up by 2.4% year-on-year, 6.5 state and quarter-on-quarter we are down by 0.7 and 3.6 if we consider stated, and the constant ForEx and perimeter, despite of the fact that in Central/Eastern Europe we have a 16.2% year-on-year growth due to the branch opening.

I want to clarify this branch opening plan and with the plan presentation you will see also detailed numbers on that. It is quite important for us because the breakeven in Central/Eastern Europe is achieved in the best case in 12 months, in the worst case in 18 months. So the payback of these investments is fantastically good and it's quite important for us to continue to grow in order to create a significant NPV from this investment process.

Depreciation is down quarter-on-quarter, is slightly up year-on-year. As you can see if we consider constant ForEx and perimeter we are almost flat. So we think that overall the cost control is quite good and again is coming mainly from the integration of Capitalia, but also the HVB and Bank Austria rationalization continue to pay off.

Talking of full time equivalent. This is again a demonstration of the fact that we must be -- as I am used to say little bit , because on one side we have to continue to reduce the cost and to increase efficiency in the ongoing activity. And on the other side we have to invest for continuing to create value in terms of growth. So on one side, we have a significant reduction, 2400 people in one quarter. On the ... we can talk of planning activities. 600 people coming from outsourcing and disposal, 1600 Italy decreased. 200 people coming from other efficiency we are achieving mainly in Germany. Then we have 1200 people hired in countries where we are opening branches in Central/Eastern Europe. We have 600 people coming from so-called other Central/Eastern European countries, 444 people; Italy 143 and also 25, mainly in the leasing business. Then we have a new consolidation. 11,444 people is mainly Ukrotsbank, leasing in HVB and Infotech in GBS Austria are all companies we are bringing in the perimeter in order to be able to increase the rationalization of the process.

In terms of branch opening, you see the detail. Turkey is close to one half of the opening we have in Central/Eastern Europe; is slightly more than the plan in the sense that we are accelerating when we see opportunities to have a good location and to reduce the number of months in which we can achieve the break-even point. So, in the first quarter we have opened 100 branches, out of it, 512 branches we are planning to open in Central/Eastern Europe in this year. As I said, the 41 Italian, but Roberto can give more details. It is the tail of the program we had for all covering better Lombardi and Tuscany; that also with the Capitalia remain two regions where we want to be stronger than before.

Talking of asset quality, as we said, the net impaired loans is improving significantly. The percentage on total net loans as well is continuing to improve quite well. The coverage ratio is improved again so we are quite satisfied with the continuous risking that we have in our balance sheet.

And talking of provisions, I think that this page is quite important and the assets well under 755 million can create some confusion or worry in an understandable way. This 755 million would be 682 without Ukrsotsbank and net the change of perimeter and the 20 million we had already provision in corporate banking as a recent revision that has been moved from other recent provision to credit provision. So we have this change from what we are. Then in the 682, there are 47 million of high-yield provisions on the bank at Roma and Capitalia. So, Capitalia -- would in the comparison of the first quarter '07 where the provisions were relatively low to the first quarter of this year.

So if you don't consider also this 47, in reality we are comparing 620 with 635. That if we consider the gross we had in the long base in the previous UniCredit Group is quite a good result and is related to the quality control we have on our risk portfolio. The cost of risk is aligned with our budget so, we are perfect in line with our expectations over 56 basis points.

Talking of the results from the operating profit to the net income, you see that we had 51 million of provisions for risks and charges, 24 million integration cost -- 755 million I've just talk about. We had a 200 million of net income from investments, disposal of custodian business of former Capitalia, mainly. The tax rate is 25.7%, is lower 5 percentage wise, and if you see here -- if you remember that in the last quarter of '07 we had an exceptional one-off cost related to the change in the fiscal system in Germany and Italy and this is a result of that. Then we have the minorities, the PPA for Capitalia and we go down to the 1 billion net profit.

Talking of our capital position, in terms of quarter one, we are at 5.5, again inline with the Basel. We have built at the beginning of the year, a 22 basis point of this absorption come from the acquisition of Ukrsotsbank. Then we have the risk- weighted asset growth of 80 million. This is coming partially from the usual business, partially from the fact that the higher volatility increased the VaR and so increased the risk-weighted asset related to market activity. And, partially, 3 billion, is not very well and I'm not even indicated 3 billion of effects we have, and one of the some coverage we had on same position because we are efficient in Basel I, are not efficient, will not be efficient in Basel II since we've been authorized to use Basel II, we had this change in coverage.

We continue to have the target and we can confirm after the first quarter over 6% by the year-end, partially coming from the disposal of -- and it is the next stage -- of activities that already in the plan: former Capitalia branches, BPH as we know, the exercise of the generally convertible bond and so on. We have risk-weighted asset optimization project undergoing. On the other side, we know that during this year, we have -- we think that now there's another process is still ongoing. But we had an important step in Germany. Let's put it out of HVB and back out, so overall, considering the consumption and the capital generation we have, we confirm the target of 6% by the year-end.

On the concept of the capital position, is clear also to us as we have defined the target some years ago, 6.8% in terms of 41. So, we know perfectly that we would like to be at 6.8. This is continued to be the long-term target, it has not changed at all. And this gives us a clearer view on the fact that we are in a world that our portfolio of activities is calling for an higher core Tier I.

Having said so – so the process is in this data exchange. Having said so, we had decided to do some acquisition, mainly Ukrsotsbank and that yes, and this squeeze out. So in a moment in which the market situation were different. So, we were thinking that through this kind of asset optimization mainly via securitization we could achieve the 6.8, despite of this capital use.

Now we know that the securitization market is almost blocked. We think that we can make because we are starting to see some signal. But again, we are not considering in this plan and we consider ourself also in a stress scenario in the case of a stress -- stress scenario. With the capital base that can consent to us to manage properly our group. We don't have significant internal cushion unless we will decide to liquidate or to sell some business, which is something that we are not foreseeing as a necessity today.

So, we are aware of this situation and because again there are lot of talks on our capital position. We are confident with this capital position, continue to think that we want to go to 6.8. We think that with the 6% of Core Tier I Basel I. In Basel II, we do expect to have benefits. So again, we are confident that the capital base is allowing us to continue to grow and to continue to manage properly our business. If there will be a dramatic recession in Western Asia, today we are not foreseeing this case, clearly, the increase in PD and consequently in risk-rated asset, there would stretch our capital base. But again, we are confident that with this capital position, we can continue to manage quite well the growth.

So in order to expand and to clarify that we are aware of the fact that we are not in high end of our target because 6% is below 6.8, which has been defined three years ago as a target, so we know perfectly that. We are continuing to manage very strictly our risk-rated asset growth and the capital base. I think we have been very current in terms also disposal of non-core assets, and again, we are capable to manage properly the growth of the Group.

We have also to say that in the 550 billion of risk-weighted assets, we have a portion of risk-weighted assets with negative EVA or with low EVA and we have significant room for improving risk-weighted asset value.

Division's highlights. We have a significant EVA creation from the commercial banking activities, which is quite important. Then MIB had a negative EVA. I confirm that MIB is a business that in a usual normal market condition, not exceptional, but in a normal market condition will provide to the Group more or less 1.5 billion of pre-tax profit. So it's a business which is very relevant for us in order to be able to increase the value of the customer base we have, both corporate and retail. And we continue to provide without direction of market risk, 1.5 billion of pre-tax profit in a normalized market. So I think that this result of this period of time must be considered really as total one-off.

Having said so retail, retail is doing quite well, because continue to grow in terms of revenues, 4.3%, as I said coming from Italy, more than Germany and Austria. The revenue base in Germany and Austria is negative year-on-year, but the cost reduction is quite significant. The operating cost, as you're seeing are down by 0.8% year-on-year. So the operating profit is up by 14%. The net write-downs are slightly higher coming mainly from the growth we had in the volumes. So at the end the profit before tax do have a solid double-digit growth and we are quite satisfied with that.

The cost income ratio is decreasing a little bit. We are at 62.2%. So overall the EVA is growing by 40.4% year-on-year. We have to say that the Capitalia, where the growth is quite fantastic in terms of revenues. We are up close to, Roberto, in the Capitalia were the double-digit, so is quite significant and this is very important.

Talking of the flows of total financial assets of households, I think it's quite important. We had a negative outflow from the asset management produced by 3.8 billion. Clearly this is related to the market condition partially to meet the -- where things there start to be also some investment opportunities. So we are with Pioneer launching a series of new products in order to be able to partially offset this outflow. Obvious, then what is happening in the other two main voices of total financial assets -- assets under cost capacity went up by 2.3 billion and direct deposits went up by 3.2 billion. So, overall we had in the first quarter a positive growth of total financial asset by 1.7 billion.

It is very important because it is to review an AuM the fact these assets are moving from assets under management to asset under capital and direct deposit, and then we have a growth. The growth is coming also from the acquisition of new customers.

As I was saying when I was talking of the fee and commission line, one of the key elements for us has been the selling of the Genius One, which is very important for us, in order to be able to continue to reduce the cost structure of the group. So, it is very important, this factor. We have sold 150,000 of these accounts.

New activity coming from the Capitalia Group – world, I think it's a very important. We started to move pretty well in terms of net new current accounts. Capitalia was losing new current accounts. Now we're gaining new current accounts. We have an annualized growth of 3.5%. We are still slightly below what UniCredit Banca is capable to do, but the trend is very positive 3.5% vis-à-vis 4% of annualized growth, 25,000 new current accounts.

The gross margin from sales of investment products is growing quite well, catching up the gap that was and there is with UniCredit Banca World. And also there is more business, short term loan stock is growing quite significantly. We have a year-on-year growth of 35% vis-à-vis the 16% we had in UniCredit Banca. So overall and again the up-closing and the contribution coming from Capitalia to is quite important. As we said we had 93% growth of the overall retail, we have double digit growth for the Capitalia World, is single digit growth for UniCredit Banca. The weighted average is 9.3%.

The cost is going down mainly thanks to the reduction of staff expenses, where we continue to increase efficiency. You can consider that we have reduced of 900 people, the staff in the first quarter is even more year-on-year. Despite the effect in this period of time, in one year from March '07 to March '08, we have opened 113 new branches in retail in Italy and again this is to call the 80% of these branches are in Lombardi and Tuscany. So we have been able to finance this growth and in the meanwhile to reduce the staff expenses. And again this is a very significant activity. We are realizing because we are moving transaction from the desk to other channels in order to become more efficient in terms of transaction there -- capital. So it's a very long process.

On the other hand administrative expenses, we are also almost flat. We are slightly down year-on-year. We have a very significant improvement in Austria and Germany. In Austria the cost reduction is 11.5%, in Germany is 4.4%. Again it's important because when we consider ourselves, a restructuring story on one side and the growth story on the other side you see it's demonstrated by these two factors. This is very, very important, because if we don't consider the group as different elements also the cost side can be misleading, because again when we are financing the opening of new branches in Central and Eastern Europe quite clearly, we are making a choices to have good will or to have cost.

The good will are not depreciated, unless if there is an impairment, but in any case are non-tangible equity, while the costs are on the profit and loss. We are always working in terms of NTB. So if there is an opportunity for an acquisition where we have a good repayment, it's the right way to grow through the acquisition. You are by far faster because you are acquiring immediately market share, restructuring potentiality and so on. But on the other side we know that the cost per branch is significantly higher than one we have when we open branch.

Also in the acquisition we are talking about run of Central/Eastern Europe. If we talk of, for instance, Kazakhstan. Kazakhstan, if we consider the budget that we will realize this year, in terms of net profit, is cash accretive in the first year. This is very, very important because the cost of funding of the acquisition of Kazakhstan is lower than the net profit that we will have at the group level in the first year. So at the end we have to consider all this settlements.

We had an increase on the cost side and we're taking Italy due to the branch opening and growth project. Also financing internationalization which is booked in Italy because UniCredit financing is based in Italy, as you know, we are opening this connection in Germany, Bulgaria, Romania and Poland. So, we are financing this growth. But again this is very, very important because we will go across our captive cost on our base.

MIB, we had this negative number coming from the evaluation of the ABS portfolio, plus a portfolio of floating rate notes of banks that is a portfolio we have for liquidity reason. So where MIB spread has moved significantly in the first quarter due mainly to the Delspan event. So at the end you will see, I think, it's more relevant to go to the four following pages, the numbers considering this activities out of the revenue base.

So talking of our first quarter results we have the ABS portfolio which has been identified as a ring fence position to be managed as a discontinued activity, so we are managing it outside of the usual business in order to give always a number in a separate way where we had 642 negative mark-to-market, 600 million are realized losses. This loss is exactly in line with the sensitivity we gave you on the contrary. We had a small reduction of this sensitivity, because you remember we have 6 million, today we are at 5.5 million, so it's bit in the first quarter.

Clearly the market today is likely more relaxed, but in the first quarter the spread enlarged quite significantly. Then we have exact 336 negative mark-to-market with 80 million of realized losses due to current market condition, other credit related activities which remain core business. Because this is business line we had and we continue to have with mainly the credit-related activities, where we have a source of business by ourself and with other financial institutions, with customers. The remaining businesses are showing solid results with stronger plan driven activities, almost 700 million of revenues in the other business lines.

So, if we can see there, now if we see investment banking then we will see the fact that we see and market activity. In investment banking the -- we are very happy with the fact that in the first quarter we had planned there €73 million of revenue base, coming from origination and financing. We are gaining markets share. We are taking care because now as we know it's not easy to know how the market is moving, but the feeling we have is that we are gaining market share in these activities. The overall industry is down. We have from the first numbers -- but we've seen some competitors, feeling that the franchise of our customer base, on which these revenues are based, is paying.

Principle investment is slightly negative in the first quarter. We continue to foresee a revenue base in the range of between 100 and 150 million per year, this year, next year in this revenue, in this business line. As we remember, '07 has been rather exceptional, with slightly more than 300 million. This business line is quite important for us.

Again, this is a very, very fragmented portfolio of small investments. We are doing with our financial sponsor, our customers when we do other way the credit story. So, we are financing a fund and we have a right for co-investment and we do a co-investment with them in various amount and this is a quite important for us.

The most relevant rebound we had, I think is in the market business line, where you can see that if we compare the first quarter this year with the last quarter last year we have growth of 18% in the overall business line. If we consider ex credit related activities, which is we think quite good is 19% in fixed income currency and commodities and 25% in equities cash and dividends.

The Global ABS portfolio is down by close to 3 billion in the first quarter. In April, we had further reduction of 400 million, the amortization at par and sales without any loss. You can see the expected ABS volume during the date, whether there is life based on model assumptions is four years. You can see that we have 34% of amortization and repayment in '08, another 17% in '09, another 14% in '010, so 65% of the portfolio is expected to expire in '08, '09, '010, so it is quite important. In '08 we do expect to have a further action, we have amortization of 2 billion and we then will have other sales of said portfolio as soon as we have any opportunity.

Private banking. Private banking in terms of revenues is slightly higher than the previous year. Quite clearly is under pressure for market effects, because it's quite important, the assets under management activity. We had a decline in commission due to negative industry trend as it meets a significant impact which has been offset by the growth in net interest income. Now we have seen that we had a significant growth in the deposit base. The costs are quite vital and under control. Profit before tax are higher than the previous year, due to the fact that we have sold the Monte Carlo branch of Capitalia, that again is important for us, the fact that the operating profit despite of the market conditions is flat.

Asset management, we had a reduction in the revenue base which has been quite significant. We had also a significant reduction on the cost side due to the fact that we have a lower variable compensation. There is also a stock option plan which is ready to be valued of the company, so the shadow value of the company quite clearly as we know by and near is not listed and there has been a positive impact on this number.

So the operating profit is down. The profit before tax is slightly higher and the figures here are due to the disposal of the Capitalia and Custodian banking business and lower restructuring cost. So, at the end, the performance of the asset management business has been quite good. We have to say that also the operating profit for us is really good considering the market conditions.

We had negative sales coming from mainly Italy, 10 billion of negative sales in Italy. The third party distribution is slightly growing in the Italy because the captive Germany and Austria are also negative. So, at the end, we are slightly improving our position in third party distribution. We have a negative trend in the captive distribution activity. As we have seen for a more conservative position of our customers that are switching their assets in assets and their captive end deposits. We think that during the time they will come back to assets and their management.

Corporate, we have a growth in the corporate revenue by 3.2%, also net -- we will concede there the trend in hedging problems, the growth would be 6%, with a rising contribution timing from global transaction banking where we have a growth by 7% year-on-year. Net interest are up by 7.6% year-on-year and non-net interest income would be flat if we wouldn't consider the derivative and businesses. So, at the end, we are, again, quite positive on that.

The operating costs are up 3.2%, mainly coming from global leasing expansion in Central/Eastern Europe. As you know, we have 13 countries where we have a local company which is also very important for us and the Capitalia integration. Net write-downs on loans are up mainly due to 20 million of reclassification and higher provisions due to the rise of landing volumes. So at the end, profit before taxes are slightly down, but we do see a positive trend if we would consider the trend without this one-off.

Central/Eastern Europe is growing quite significantly as we have seen the total revenues would be 24% up at constant ForEx are 11.2%, 24% considering Ukrsotsbank and ATF. The operating costs are up by 13.1%, without the branch openings would be 9.5%. So the operating profit is up 9.3%. Net write-down on loans are higher year-on-year, but without the change of parameter would be down by 11.5%. So, profit before tax would be 17.4% higher at cost under ForEx parameter, and net income 11%.

If we consider the growth rate we're having in terms of branch opening, we think that also the cost income ratio is quite good, because it's a 49.7 with the thought we are heading for this opening branch plan is quite a good cost income ratio.

Talking of the split of the revenue base, you see that the Poland clearly is leading player, 38% in the first quarter. In '07 year-on-year it was 41%. So, Poland is slightly decreasing, as of '08 the countries are growing more. Despite, '08's slowdown we had in Poland in the asset management business the revenue basis is upper one by 1.2% year-on-year. As you remember, the asset management business in first quarter last year was quite exceptional. So, we are also very happy with the performance of Poland.

The other countries are growing very significantly. In Turkey we are close to 31% ratio, 18%, Russia 25%, Czech Republic 1.3% year-on-year, it would be 10% net of trading. Also in Hungary, we have a negative growth, 2.3% would be 15.3% net of trading.
